The text discusses the different types of viruses that can be found in stool samples, including both cultivable and non-cultivable or "fastidious" viruses. Non-cultivable viruses have been associated with many cases of diarrhea, while certain strains of Norwalk virus, calicivirus, astrovirus, SRSV, and SRV appear to be capable of causing outbreaks. The text also mentions that specific or catch-all methods are used for diagnosis, including electron microscopy, polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis, latex agglutination, and enzyme immunoassays. False positive and negative results can occur with these methods, and in an outbreak it is essential to make electron microscopic examinations. In individual cases where no electron microscope is available, the diagnosis of rotavirus and perhaps adenoviruses (all types or only 40 and 41) can be made with a commercial kit, but a small number of stools may contain multiple viruses.

The article discusses the potential benefits of universal repeated testing for COVID-19 in high-risk areas, as an alternative to the current lockdown measures. The authors suggest that weekly severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) antigen testing of the whole population in a demonstration site (preferably several towns and cities) with strict household quarantine after a positive test could help control the epidemic. The testing program would assess feasibility in one or more cities with 200,000-300,000 people, and if successful, could be rolled out nationally. The authors argue that such a strategy could save hundreds of thousands of lives, reduce the strain on intensive care units, and mitigate the adverse effects of lockdown on mental ill health and unemployment. They also suggest that real-time evidence from the testing program would enable policy to be based on actual infection rates rather than modeling assumptions.

The article discusses the use of hypochlorous acid (HOCl) as a potential disinfectant against the COVID-19 virus in an oral-maxillofacial clinic setting. The authors reviewed the literature to determine the effectiveness of HOCl in different locations and industries, and found that it can be used with high predictability for disinfecting against the COVID-19 virus. They suggest that HOCl is an inexpensive, available, non-toxic, and practical disinfectant that can be used on a daily basis to limit the spread of the virus between healthcare providers and patients. The article highlights the importance of disinfecting surfaces potentially exposed to COVID-19 to prevent transmission, and concludes that HOCl is a promising solution for this purpose.

Summary: Researchers are exploring various approaches to combat SARS-CoV-2, including a combinational contemporary strategy that involves three compelling processes: Specificity, Remedy, and a Conveyor. The Specificity process involves expressing ACE2 receptors in conveyor cells to deceive SARS-CoV-2 from prepone targets. The Remedy process proposes an entity of a cost-effective artificial surfactant system as a remedy to pulmonary complications caused by depletion of pulmonary surfactants. The Conveyor process involves using red blood cells (RBCs) as a conveyor with embedded artificial surfactant and protruding ACE2 receptors for target-specific delivery. Overall, the strategy aims to provide focused insights into combating SARS-CoV-2.

In this study, the authors present various approaches to model the evolution of the COVID-19 epidemic in Argentina, with a particular focus on the megacity of Buenos Aires and its metropolitan area. They highlight the importance of considering the early stages of the epidemic in light of incoming infectious travelers from abroad. The authors then critically evaluate proposed solutions to contain the epidemic based on instantaneous modifications of the reproductive number, and build increasingly complex and realistic models using mobility estimates from cell phone location data. These models are capable of producing forecasts highly consistent with the official number of cases with minimal parameter fitting and fine-tuning. The authors discuss the strengths and limitations of the proposed models, emphasizing the need for careful interpretation of long-term forecasts and cautious adoption of non-pharmaceutical interventions.

Since January 2020, Elsevier has created a COVID-19 resource center with free information in English and Mandarin on the novel coronavirus COVID-19. The company grants permission to make all its COVID-19-related research available in publicly funded repositories, including PubMed Central, with rights for unrestricted research re-use and analysis. A case series from China found that 15.5% of patients with COVID-19 show evidence of kidney injury on presentation, with 3.2% developing acute kidney injury during hospitalization. A 44-year-old African American woman with known chronic kidney disease and poorly controlled diabetes mellitus type 2 presented to the emergency department with fever, vomiting, worsening cough, and flank pain. She was found to have acute kidney injury with a serum creatinine of 4.0 mg/dl superimposed on known chronic kidney disease. The patient's medical history, physical examination, and laboratory results are presented in the article.

The article introduces COVIDep, a web-based platform that provides immune target recommendations for guiding the development of SARS-CoV-2 vaccines. The platform uses publicly available genetic data for SARS-CoV-2 and epitope data for SARS-CoV to identify B cell and T cell epitopes that could serve as vaccine targets. COVIDep is user-friendly, flexible, and updated periodically as new data becomes available. The platform exploits the genetic similarities between SARS-CoV-2 and SARS-CoV to identify epitopes that are likely to induce a cross-reactive immune response against SARS-CoV-2. Experimental results have shown that specific antibodies binding to the spike protein of SARS-CoV-2 have limited cross-reactivity, while antibody and T cell responses against epitopes that are genetically similar in SARS-CoV and SARS-CoV-2 have been reported in COVID-19 infected patients and in preclinical vaccine trials.

In this study, the authors aimed to estimate the serial interval and basic reproduction number (R0) for COVID-19 in Jodhpur, India, and use these estimates to predict the epidemic size over the next one month. They used contact tracing of infected individuals to obtain serial intervals, and derived aggregate and instantaneous R0 values. The overall R0 value in the first 30 days of the outbreak was 1.64, which subsequently decreased to 1.07. The instantaneous R0 value over a 14-day window ranged from a peak of 3.71 to 0.88 as of June 24, 2020. The projected COVID-19 case-load over the next one month was 1881 individuals. Reducing the R0 value from 1.17 to 1.085 could result in a 23% reduction in projected epidemic size over the next one month. The study suggests that aggressive testing, contact-tracing, and isolation of infected individuals can reduce the R0 value, leading to a substantial reduction in the COVID-19 epidemic size. A data-driven strategy was found useful in surge capacity planning and guiding the public health strategy at the local level.

In this study, the researchers investigated whether there are gender-related differences in the effects of antenatal betamethasone exposure on the angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) and ACE2 pathways in the kidney cortex of male and female sheep. The study found that while there were no differences in ACE or ACE2 protein expression between betamethasone-treated animals and controls of the same gender, there was a significant gender-related difference in ACE2 protein expression. Specifically, ACE2 expression in the renal cortex of male sheep was reduced by 54% compared to female sheep. These findings suggest that antenatal steroid exposure does not result in alterations of ACE and ACE2 in the kidney cortex, but that there are gender-related differences in the effects of steroid exposure on these enzymes. This may contribute to previously described gender differences in sodium handling and hypertension among offspring exposed to betamethasone.

Summary: Spotted hyenas are capable hunters that have recently descended from carrion-feeding ancestors. Despite exposure to various pathogens, including anthrax, rabies, and canine distemper virus (CDV), spotted hyenas have shown remarkable disease resistance. Researchers aimed to identify tools for studying immune function in spotted hyenas and tested the cross-reactivity of anti-feline antibodies with hyena immunoglobulin epitopes. The study found that the full array of isotype-specific antibodies identified can be used to thoroughly investigate the hyena antibody response and test hypotheses about pathogen exposure and immune function in this species. The findings suggest that the immune systems of carnivores specialized for scavenging have been shaped by selective pressures associated with surviving microbial assaults from their food.

In this study, the researchers evaluated the expression of certain cell surface antigens (CD4, CD8, CD25, CD14, and CD74) in the alveolar septa of lung tissue samples from autopsies of immunocompetent children who died of severe acute respiratory infections. They found that the number of TCD8+ lymphocytes (a type of immune cell) was higher in cases of viral pneumonia, and that CD14+ cell numbers were often reduced in cases of adenovirus infection. The study suggests that the cellular response plays a critical role in recovery from acute viral respiratory infections, and that individuals with impaired cellular immunity may have more severe diseases and longer virus secretion periods.

In this study, researchers investigated whether a primary infection with porcine reproductive and respiratory syndrome (PRRS) virus influences the clinical outcome of experimentally induced classical swine fever (CSF) in young pigs. The study involved 15 6-week-old crossbred weaners that were randomly divided into three groups: one group was inoculated with PRRS virus followed by CSF virus 3 days later, another group received CSF virus only, and the third group was inoculated with PRRS virus only. The study found that the PRRS virus-infected pigs developed mild respiratory symptoms and recovered completely, while all five pigs inoculated with CSF virus only showed severe clinical signs typical of the acute form of CSF. One pig had to be killed 15 days post-inoculation (p.i.), and the remaining four died between days 18 and 22 p.i. The study concluded that the observed divergences in the clinical courses would not have been noticed under field conditions, casting doubt on the relevance of PRRS virus infection potentiating significantly the clinical outcome of CSF in young pigs.

The COVID-19 pandemic has led to an unprecedented reduction in global economic activity, resulting in lower levels of air pollution, particularly from land transportation. Using data from over 10,000 air quality stations across 34 countries during lockdown periods until May 2020, the study found significant reductions in nitrogen dioxide (NO2), ozone (O3), and particulate matter smaller than 2.5 micrometers in diameter (PM2.5). The study estimated that there were approximately 49,900 excess deaths and 89,000 pediatric asthma emergency room visits avoided during lockdowns. In China and India alone, the PM2.5-related avoided excess mortality was 19,600 and 30,500, respectively. The study suggests that reducing "business as usual" air pollutant emissions from economic activities through alternative transportation solutions could lead to significant health benefits.

Neuroactive steroids are endogenous molecules that can rapidly alter neuronal excitability by binding to membrane receptors. They are synthesized in the brain from cholesterol through a complex process involving several enzymes, including the translocator protein 18 kDa (TSPO), the steroidogenic acute regulatory protein (StAR), and the voltage-dependent anion channel protein (VDAC). The synthesis of neuroactive steroids occurs primarily in principal neurons of several brain areas that possess the necessary enzymatic machinery. The most potent neuroactive steroids are 3a,5a-3-hydroxypregnan-20-one (3a,5a-THP) and 3a,5a-3,21-dihydroxypregnan-20-one (3a,5a-THDOC), which enhance GABAA receptor mediated neurotransmission and produce inhibitory neurobehavioural effects. Specific binding sites for neuroactive steroids have been identified on the a subunits of the GABAA receptor that allosterically modulate binding to GABA and benzodiazepine recognition sites. Neuroactive steroids also modulate synaptic and extrasynaptic GABAA receptors, as well as other receptors such as serotonin type 3 receptors, neuronal nicotinic acetylcholine receptors, and voltage-activated calcium channels.

The text describes the synthesis and evaluation of peptides corresponding to different regions of the HIV-1 protease enzyme, with the goal of identifying potential inhibitors of the enzyme. The HIV-1 protease is a major target for antiviral drug design due to its essential role in the replication of the virus. The structure of the HIV-1 protease has been elucidated through X-ray crystallography, revealing that it is composed of 99 amino acid residues and assembles into a homodimer. The dimeric nature of the enzyme offers a new mode of inhibition beyond active site inhibition. The study focused on the region around the N- and C-termini of the homodimer, which accounts for approximately 50% of the interface between the monomers. This region contains a four-stranded antiparallel p sheet structure. Peptides corresponding to the C- or N-terminal regions were synthesized and evaluated for their ability to inhibit HIV-1 protease activity or HIV-1 production in vitro. The results showed that some of the peptides had a decrease in HIV-1 protease activity or HIV-1 production, suggesting that they may be effective inhibitors of the enzyme.

In summary, the article discusses the challenges of accurately dating bruises in children based on their color. The authors reviewed existing literature and found that there is little scientific basis for aging bruises based solely on color. They emphasize the importance of considering a child's complete medical history and physical examination when evaluating bruises, rather than relying solely on color as an indicator of age. The article also notes that there is variation in human color discrimination, which can further complicate the accuracy of bruise aging. The authors conclude that while Sugar and colleagues' 1999 article is often cited in the field, more rigorous research is needed to improve the accuracy of bruise aging.

In this article, the authors describe their experiences as young residents in internal medicine fighting COVID-19 at Antwerp University Hospital in Belgium. They explain how public health measures such as social distancing and quarantine were implemented rapidly to slow down the spread of the virus, and how they were quickly deployed to work in the Covid-wards. The authors highlight the challenges they faced, including frequent clinical check-ups and logistical problems, as they cared for COVID-19 positive patients who could deteriorate rapidly. They also mention that this experience has opened a new chapter in their medical training.

In January 2020, Elsevier created a COVID-19 resource center with free information in English and Mandarin on the novel coronavirus. The center is hosted on Elsevier Connect, the company's public news and information website. Elsevier grants permission to make all COVID-19-related research available on the resource center, including this commentary, for unrestricted research re-use and analysis in any form or by any means with acknowledgement of the original source. The commentary describes improvisations of emergency tracheostomies during the last month of lockdown for COVID-19 in a head and neck surgical oncology unit in Kerala, India. Eleven patients were treated for airway compromise due to cancer-related stridor during the pandemic, and four were managed conservatively while seven underwent emergency tracheostomy whose COVID status was unknown. The surgical team took appropriate measures to ensure safety during the procedures, including donning personal protective equipment (PPE) and performing buddy checks to ensure completeness of donning. All tracheostomies were performed under monitored anesthesia care (MAC).

The COVID-19 pandemic has brought numerous challenges to the world, including a rapid spread of the virus, high death toll, and enforcement of lockdowns. Research has shown that there is a significant increase in psychological and mental health disorders during the pandemic. This study focuses on the condition of coronavirus fear, mental health, preventive behavior, and anxiety disorder among people in Khyber Pakhtunkhwa (KPK), Pakistan. Due to lockdown and mobility restrictions imposed by the provincial government, manual/physical data collection was not possible, so an online survey was designed using Google forms to gather data from respondents. The survey was completed by 501 respondents through various online platforms, including social media, personal contact points, and social applications like Facebook, WhatsApp, and LinkedIn.

The article discusses the role of integrins in the uptake of coronaviruses by host cells. The authors propose that the cellular internalization of αvβ3 integrin applies to the uptake of coronaviruses bound to the integrin, and suggest that clinical host T4 may contribute to target cell uptake of coronavirus and the consequence of cell uptake of the virus. The article highlights the possibility that thyroid hormone analogues, such as deaminated T4 and deaminated 3,5,3ʹ-triiodo-L-thyronine (T3), may block the virus-relevant actions of T4 at integrin αvβ3 and possibly restrict virus uptake. The authors also note that ACE2 modulates the intracellular signaling generated by integrins, and suggest that a distinction between integrins and ACE2 in terms of uptake of coronaviruses such as SARS-CoV-2 and intracellular signaling induced by viruses may be increasingly difficult to establish. The article concludes that pharmacologic options exist to prevent internalization of the integrin and bound virus, as discussed below.

The study investigated the effects of the COVID-19 lockdown on blood glucose control in individuals with type 1 diabetes (T1D). Fifty T1D patients were recruited and their glucose levels were monitored using continuous or flash glucose monitoring systems. The results showed that the time in range (TIR) significantly decreased during the lockdown period, while mean glucose levels (MG) and estimated HbA1c increased. Additionally, there was a significant association between work instability and impaired TIR after adjustment for potential confounders. The study suggests that prolonged restrictions and massive lifestyle changes can affect frail individuals and those with chronic diseases, such as T1D patients.

The study investigated the role of angiotensin-converting enzyme-II (ACE2) in mediating the entry of SARS-CoV-2 into host cells by binding to the receptor-binding domain (RBD) of the viral spike protein. The study used computational site-directed mutagenesis and molecular dynamics simulations to analyze how mutations in the RBD affect the molecular interaction with ACE2. The results showed that loss of important intermolecular hydrogen bonds and other non-bonded contacts between the RBD and ACE2 were observed in mutant complexes, indicating that these interactions are crucial for recognition of SARS-CoV-2 by ACE2. Additionally, the study found that the RBM motif is flexible, with mutant residues being more mobile than wild-type residues. The study concluded that the findings provide detailed information on the structural basis of receptor binding by human SARS-CoV-2 and will be crucial for the development of novel inhibitors or drugs to combat against SARS-CoV-2.

In this chapter, the authors detail various experimental approaches to characterize the fuzziness of complexes formed between the C-terminal domain of the nucleoprotein (NTAIL) from three representative paramyxoviruses and the C-terminal X domain (XD) of the homologous phosphoprotein. The authors discuss the advantages, limitations, and caveats of each method and provide experimental data showing that paramyxoviral NTAIL–XD complexes exhibit a significant amount of conformational heterogeneity. They also detail recent findings revealing that NTAIL is highly malleable, meaning it displays partner-mediated polymorphism. The authors use size-exclusion chromatography (SEC) to determine the Stokes radius of the complex and compare it to the value expected for a fully folded complex made of protein A and protein B. They also discuss the technical limitations of SEC in detecting complex formation, which can be overcome by using multiple angle laser light scattering (SEC-MALLS) to directly measure the Stokes radius and molecular mass of the complex.

In this study, the authors aim to develop a simple average aggregated machine learning method to predict the number, size, and duration of COVID-19 cases in India. They analyze the datasets using Autoregressive Integrated Moving Average Model (ARIMA) and compare the performance of three regression techniques: Support Vector Regression (SVR), Neural Network, and Linear Regression. The results show that COVID-19 can be accurately predicted, and the method outperforms previously obtained practical models in terms of prediction accuracy. The study suggests that implementing preventive measures such as social distancing, wearing masks and gloves, and staying at home can help reduce the spread of the disease and lower mortality rates. Keywords: Support Vector Regression, Neural Network, Linear Regression, COVID-19 Epidemic, Machine Learning, Prediction, Viruses.

Since January 2020, Elsevier has created a COVID-19 resource center with free information in English and Mandarin on the novel coronavirus COVID-19. The resource center is hosted on Elsevier Connect, the company's public news and information website. Elsevier grants permission to make all its COVID-19-related research available in publicly funded repositories, including PubMed Central, with rights for unrestricted research re-use and analysis. OCSiAl, a Russian company, plans to expand its graphene nanotube production further to meet growing demand, with a first production line scheduled for commissioning in 2023. Lanxess, a German specialty chemicals company, had a successful fiscal year in 2019 despite the challenging global economic environment, achieving a record margin and generating EBITDA pre-exceptionals of E1.019 billion and net income from continuing operations of E240 million on net sales of E6.802 billion. The company restated its figures for 2018 to account for divested chrome chemicals and chrome ore mining activities, and reclassified its Leather business unit as a discontinued operation.

The article discusses a new method for analyzing genetic and environmental data in the context of complex disease studies. The method allows for the estimation of multiple levels of disease status using a maximum likelihood approach with an EM algorithm. The authors extend previous work by Chatterjee and Carroll (2005) to handle missing information in the environmental exposure variables, and propose a new way to correct for measurement error in these variables. The method is illustrated through simulations and applied to a case-control study on the relationship between calcium intake and colorectal adenoma risk.

In this study, the authors investigated the effectiveness of peptide-coated vascular grafts in preventing intimal tissue growth and promoting endothelial cell lining in sheep. The study found that P15-coated ePTFE grafts had less intimal tissue growth at the venous side of the anastomosis compared to uncoated grafts. Additionally, the degree of endothelial cell lining was higher for coated samples than uncoated ones. These findings suggest that P15-coated ePTFE graft materials have improved cell adhesion, proliferation, and migration compared to uncoated grafts. The study's results have implications for the prevention of vascular access failure in patients with end-stage renal disease, as well as reducing hospitalizations and costs associated with thrombectomies.

The nonstructural protein P9-1 of Rice black streaked dwarf virus (RBSDV) has been confirmed to accumulate in viroplasms, the putative sites of viral replication, in infected plants and insects. The study used RNA interference (RNAi) to knockdown the expression of P9-1 in rice plants, resulting in resistance to RBSDV infection. The findings suggest that targeting a viroplasm component protein of plant reoviruses, such as P9-1, may be a practical and effective way to control plant reovirus infection in crop plants.

Prostate cancer is a significant public health burden and leading cause of cancer-related morbidity and mortality in the United States, despite a decline in annual prostate cancer-specific mortality rates over the past decade. The review aims to summarize recent therapeutic advances in prostate cancer treatment based on current understanding of prostate cancer biology. The literature search conducted in 2009 using PubMed identified studies on advanced prostate cancer therapeutics published in the past 5-10 years, as well as novel hormonal agents targeting the androgen receptor currently in development. These include 5α-reductase inhibitors, androgen deprivation therapy, and new hormonal agents such as bicalutamide and enzalutamide. The review highlights the importance of ongoing research to improve treatment outcomes for patients with advanced prostate cancer.

The article discusses the use of two antiviral drugs, amantadine and rimantadine, for the prevention and treatment of influenza A infections. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) and the World Health Organization (WHO) recommend consulting their guidelines before using these drugs clinically, including against novel strains of avian H5N1 influenza. A triple drug regimen consisting of amantadine, ribavirin, and oseltamivir is currently being studied for the treatment of influenza A infections, including those resistant to adamantane-type drugs. Both amantadine and rimantadine are effective against susceptible strains, with peak levels achieved 3-5 hours after ingestion. However, resistance to both drugs has emerged within 2-4 days in up to 30% of patients, and spread to contacts can lead to failures of antiviral prophylaxis in nursing homes and households. The most common side effects of the M2 inhibitors are minor CNS complaints and gastrointestinal upset, particularly in the elderly and those with renal failure. Drug-drug interactions should be considered when co-administering these agents with other medications. Cross-resistance to both drugs occurs due to single amino acid substitutions in the transmembrane portion of the M2 protein.

In this study, the authors investigated the spatial and cellular localization of Dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4), a type II transmembrane ectopeptidase, in the lungs of individuals infected with Middle Eastern respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV). They found that DPP4 was rarely detected in the surface epithelium of the nasal cavity and conducting airways, but was more frequently found in distal airways. DPP4 was also detected in a subset of mononuclear leukocytes and serous cells of submucosal glands in the parenchyma. The study suggests that preexisting pulmonary disease could increase the abundance of DPP4, the receptor for MERS-CoV, in the lungs, which may predispose individuals to MERS morbidity and mortality. The finding that DPP4 is principally found in type I and II cells and alveolar macrophages in the parenchyma may explain why MERS is characterized by lower respiratory tract disease.
